column1: ==='apes in the dark forests of the South'===

{{quote|Against the Deeping Wall the hosts of Isengard roared like a sea. Orcs and hillmen swarmed about its feet from end to end. Ropes with grappling hooks were hurled over the parapet faster than men could cut them or fling them back. Hundreds of long ladders were lifted up. Many were cast down in ruin
column2: but many more replaced them
column3: and Orcs sprang up them like apes in the dark forests of the South.|[[Helm's Deep]]

column1: {{quote|One day a neighbour’s pet monkeys climbed over the wall and chewed up three of the baby’s [Tolkien’s] pinafores.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}
{{quote|Red Indians were better: there were bows and arrows (I had and have a wholly unsatisfied desire to shoot well with a bow)...|[[On Fairy-Stories]]}}
{{quote|But he [Tolkien] liked Red Indian stories and longed to shoot with a bow and arrow.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

column2: called Bag End by the locals
column3: in Dormston

column1: {{quote|It [Bag End] was the local name for my aunt's [Jane Neave] farm in Worcestershire
column2: which was at the end of a lane leading to it and no further ...|[[Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings|Nomenclature]]}}

column1: {{quote|Intended to recall bag — cf. Bilbo’s conversation with Smaug in The H. [Chapter 12] — and meant to be associated (by hobbits) with Bag End ...|[[Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings|Nomenclature]]}}
{{quote|He [the Bullroarer] charged the ranks of the goblins of Mount Gram in the Battle of the Green Fields
column2: and knocked their king Golfimbul's head clean off with a wooden club.|[[An Unexpected Party]]
column3: [[The Hobbit]]}}

column1: {{quote|She [Tolkien’s aunt Grace] alleged that the family name ['Tolkien'] had originally been ‘von Hohenzollern’
column2: for they had emanated from the Hohenzollern district of the Holy Roman Empire. A certain George von Hohenzollern had
column3: she said
column4: fought on the side of Archduke Ferdinand of Austria at the Siege of Vienna in 1529. He had shown great daring in leading an unofficial raid against the Turks and capturing the Sultan’s standard. This (said Aunt Grace) was why he was given the nickname Tollkühn
column5: ‘foolhardy’; and the name stuck.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

Warwickshire
column3: England

column1: {{quote|The dead ruffians were laden on waggons and hauled off to an old sand-pit nearby and there buried: in the Battle Pit
column2: as it was afterwards called.|[[The Scouring of the Shire]]
column3: [[The Lord of the Rings]]}}

column2: a little way up the hill towards Moseley
column3: was a deep tree-lined sandpit that became another favourite haunt for the boys [Ronald and Hilary].|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

column2: Tolkien’s mother
Oxford
column3: England] bear glazed photographs of the deceased
column4: and the inscriptions are florid. In consequence a grey slab of Cornish granite rather to the left of the group stands out clearly
column5: as does its slightly curious wording: Edith Mary Tolkien

column2: meeting of===

column1: * Edith Bratt sang and danced for Tolkien in a small wood in the village of Roos
column2: Yorkshire

column1: {{quote|Blue was her [Lúthien’s] raiment as the unclouded heaven
column2: but her eyes were grey as the starlit evening; her mantle was sewn with golden flowers
column3: but her hair was dark as the shadows of twilight.|[[The Silmarillion]]}}

column2: heart-piercing was her song as the song of the lark that rises from the gates of night and pours its voice among the dying stars
column3: seeing the sun behind the walls of the world; and the song of Lúthien released the bonds of winter
column5: and flowers sprang from the cold earth where her feet had passed.|[[The Silmarillion]]}}

column1: {{quote|But wandering in the summer in the woods of Neldoreth he [Beren] came upon Lúthien
column2: daughter of Thingol and Melian
column3: at a time of evening under moonrise
column4: as she danced upon the unfading grass in the glades beside Esgalduin.|[[The Silmarillion]]}}

column1: {{quote|It [the chief part of the Silmarillion] was first conceived in a small woodland glade filled with hemlocks at Roos in Yorkshire (where I was for a brief time in command of an outpost of the Humber Garrison in 1917
column2: and she [Edith Bratt] was able to live with me for a while). In those days her hair was raven
column3: her skin clear
column4: her eyes brighter than you [Christopher Tolkien] have seen them
column5:
and she could sing – and dance.

For ever (especially when alone) we still met in the woodland glade
column6: and went hand in hand many times to escape the shadow of imminent death before our last parting.|[[Letter 340]]

column2: small and slim
column3: with grey eyes
column4: firm clear features and short dark hair.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

column1: {{quote|Near Roos they [Ronald and Edith] found a small wood with an undergrowth of hemlock
column2: and there they wandered.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

column1: {{quote|She sang and danced for him in the wood
column2: and from this came the story that was to be the centre of The Silmarillion: the tale of the mortal man Beren who loves the immortal elven-maid Lúthien Tinúviel
column3: whom he first sees dancing among hemlock in a wood.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

column2: England) being illuminated during Queen Victoria’s Diamond Jubilee in 1897 ? -
so big that the tree that grew in the field was right inside it
column3: and stood proudly near one end
column4: at the head of the chief table. Lanterns were hung on all its branches.|[[A Long-expected Party]]

column1: {{quote|Queen Victoria’s Diamond Jubilee was celebrated and the college on top of the hill in Moseley was illuminated with coloured lights.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}
* The name Bracegirdle of a character in the Horatio Hornblower novels by C.S. Forester

column2: England ?

column1: {{quote|...four miles along the Road you'll come upon a village
column2: Bree under Bree-hill
column3: with doors looking westward.|[[Fog on the Barrow-downs]]

column1: {{quote|Chetwood is a compound of Celtic and English
column2: both elements meaning 'wood'; compare Brill
column3: in Oxfordshire
column4: derived from bree + hill.|Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings}}

column1: {{quote|...it was in the one thousand six hundred and first year of the Third Age that the Fallohide brothers
column2: Marcho and Blanco
column3: set out from Bree; and having obtained permission from the high king at Fornost
column4: they crossed the brown river Baranduin with a great following of Hobbits. They passed over the Bridge of Stonebows
column5: that had been built in the days of the power of the North Kingdom
column6: and they took all the land beyond to dwell in
column7: between the river and the Far Downs.|[[The Prologue]]

column1: {{quote|By the summer of 1896 Mabel Tolkien had found somewhere cheap enough for herself and the children [Ronald and Hilary] to live independently
column2: and they moved out of Birmingham to the hamlet of Sarehole
column3: a mile or so beyond the southern edge of the city.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

column2: Tolkien’s father
Warwickshire
column3: England –

column1: {{quote|Over the road a meadow led to the River Cole
column2: little more than a broad stream
column3: and upon this stood Sarehole Mill...|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

column1: {{quote|...they [Ronald and Hilary] would scamper away from the yard
column2: and run round to a place behind the mill [at Sarehole] where there was a silent pool with swans swimming on it. At the foot of the pool the dark waters suddenly plunged over the sluice to the great wheel below: a dangerous and exciting place.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

column1: {{quote|Soon it [Hobbiton] disappeared in the folds of the darkened land
column2: and was followed by Bywater beside its grey pool.|[[Three is Company]]
column3: [[The Lord of the Rings]]}}

column1: {{quote|Bywater. Village name: as being beside the wide pool occurring in the course of the Water
column2: the main river of the Shire...|[[Guide to the Names in The Lord of the Rings]]}}
Warwickshire
column3: England

column1: {{quote|There were few houses at Sarehole beside the row of cottages where the Tolkiens lived
column2: but Hall Green village was only a little distance away down a lane and across a ford.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

column1: {{quote|The conversation in The Green Dragon at Bywater
column2: one evening in the spring of Frodo’s fiftieth year...|[[The Shadow of the Past]]
column3: [[The Lord of the Rings]]}}

column1: {{quote|I am in fact a Hobbit (in all but size). I like gardens
column2: trees and unmechanized farmlands; I smoke a pipe...|[[Letter 213]]}}

column1: {{quote|...he [Father [[Francis Xavier Morgan]]] used to sit on the ivy-covered verandah of the Oratory House [at Rednal] smoking a large cherrywood pipe; ‘the more remarkable’. Ronald recalled
column2: ‘since he never smoked except there. Possibly my own later addiction to the Pipe derives from this.’|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

column1: {{quote|In the early morning and late afternoon the child [Tolkien] would be taken into the garden
column2: where he could watch his father tending the vines or planting '''saplings''' in a piece of walled but unused ground.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}

column1: * The focus on characters walking through Tolkien's works might possibly be due to Tolkien having to walk to his first school
column2: King Edward’s School in Birmingham

column1: {{quote|The school [King Edward’s School] was in the centre of Birmingham
column2: four miles from Sarehole
column3: and for the first few weeks '''Ronald had to walk much of the way'''
column4: for his mother could not afford the train fare and the trams did not run as far as his home. Clearly this could not continue
column5: and regretfully Mabel decided that their days in the country would have to end.|[[J.R.R. Tolkien: A Biography]]}}
